Complete Blood Count (CBC): Leukopenia (low white blood cell count), anemia (low red blood cell count), and thrombocytopenia (low platelet count).
Liver Function Tests (ALT, AST, Bilirubi: Elevated liver enzymes or bilirubin levels, indicating possible hepatotoxicity or drug-related liver dysfunction.
Renal Function Tests (Creatinine, BUN): Elevated levels indicating potential kidney dysfunction, especially in transplant recipients with preexisting kidney issues.
Serum Immunoglobulins (IgG, IgA, IgM): Reduced levels due to immunosuppressive effects on B-cell function.
C-Reactive Protein (CRP): Reduced levels due to suppression of immune and inflammatory responses.
Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR): Potentially reduced due to the drugâ€™s immunosuppressive effects.
CMV PCR (Cytomegalovirus Polymerase Chai: Elevated viral load, indicating reactivation or infection due to immunosuppression.
EBV PCR (Epstein-Barr Virus Polymerase C: Elevated EBV viral load, increasing the risk of post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD).
Blood Glucose: Elevated levels, potentially contributing to new-onset diabetes after transplantation (NODAT).
Serum Potassium: Hyperkalemia (elevated potassium levels), particularly in patients with kidney impairment.
Serum Magnesium: Hypomagnesemia (low magnesium levels), often seen in transplant recipients.
Urinalysis: Proteinuria or hematuria, indicating kidney involvement or dysfunction.
T-Cell Subsets (CD3, CD4, CD8): Altered counts due to the selective immunosuppressive action on T cells.
D-Dimer: Elevated levels in cases of thromboembolic events, although rare.
CMV IgG/IgM Antibodies: Decreased response to infection due to impaired immune surveillance.
